thread.title: Coomalbidgup bushfire: WA volunteer firefighter Harry Stead tragically dies in freak accident
thread.title_full: Coomalbidgup bushfire: WA volunteer firefighter Harry Stead tragically dies in freak accident

author: VNExplorer
title: Coomalbidgup bushfire: WA volunteer firefighter Harry Stead tragically dies in freak accident
text:
Harry Stead, 21, died after falling from fire truckTragedy has rocked WA's Esperance regionREAD MORE: Family 'literally have nothing' after bushfire ripped through home
A young volunteer firefighter who tragically lost his life while battling an out-of- control bushfire has been identified, sparking an outpouring of tributes.
Harry Stead, 21, was part of a crew in a ‘private firefighting vehicle which responded to a massive blaze threatening a rural property near Coomalbidgup in Western Australia’s south on Boxing Day.
It’s understood the young volunteer fell to his death from the fire truck in a freak accident.
Mr Stead’s death has rocked the close-knit community of Cascade and was the son of Simon Stead, a well-known farmer and businessman in the Esperance region.
It’s understood he graduated from Hale School in 2020 in Perth, where he played for the Wembley Downs Football Club and more recently, University of WA, The West Australian reported.
Harry Stead (pictured at the recent Grapevine music festival) was battling a massive blaze when he fell to his death from a fire truck
The volunteer firefighter was on the frontline of an out-of-control bushfire (pictured) near Coomalbidgup when tragedy struck
Department of Fire and Emergency Services WA described the tragedy as a devastating loss that will be felt across the entire emergency services family.
Fire brigades from the other side of the country and worldwide posted condolence messages.
WA Premier Roger Cook added: ‘Our first responders put their lives on the line every day in the service of keeping our community, and our state, safe.
‘This is an absolute tragedy, and I know the thoughts of all Western Australians are with the young man’s family and friends.’
WA Police have launched an investigation into the circumstances surrounding Mr Stead’s death as arson squad detectives travelled from Perth on Wednesday.
A report will be prepared for the coroner.
Volunteer firefighter Harry Stead (pictured) lost his life while battling a massive bushfire which threatened properties near his hometown in the Esperance region
Harry Stead (pictured) was the son of a well-known farmer and businessman in the Esperance region.
WA has had a horror start to the bushfire season with dozens of homes lost in recent weeks.
Tuesday’s fatal blaze burnt more than 7000 hectares, prompting a number of road closures and emergency evacuation alerts for parts of Coomalbidgup and Cascade.
The alert was later downgraded to a watch and act.
Mr Stead is one of several firefighters who have lost their lives on the frontline in recent weeks.
There were emotional scenes as NSW firefighter Michael Kidd, 51, was farewelled last Friday, almost a fortnight after he was fatally struck by a falling wooden beam while fighting a blaze that engulfed the house at Grose Vale, in Sydney ‘s outer north-west.
A RFS volunteer firefighter also died while battling a blaze near Kyogle in northern NSW in October.
A second NSW volunteer firefighter died weeks later after being struck by a falling tree while fighting the Hudson bushfire in the state’s north-west.
Harry Stead was originally from Cascade in WA’s south but attended Hale School in Perth
By Wednesday afternoon, the fire at Coomalbidgup was at an advice alert level. Picture: DFES
